raw_comment:
Notice:
- Higher advantages for legacy applicants (especially if parent's income rank is richer).
- Being poorer with no legacy has a higher chance of admission than someone with more money with no legacy. 
- Legacy matters more even if students get the same test scores. 
Wonder:
- What advantages do students get if they don't have any legacy status?
ace_sentences: A legacy applicant is an applicant whose parent attended the university.
Some universities give higher advantages to legacy applicants.
Some universities give especially high advantages to a legacy applicant if the parent of the legacy applicant has a high income rank.
An applicant can have no legacy status.
A poorer applicant with no legacy status can have a higher chance of admission than a richer applicant with no legacy status.
Two students can get the same test scores.
Legacy status can matter more even if two students get the same test scores.
I wonder what advantages a student gets if the student has no legacy status.
